instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3_S5_EN: What is P3V3_S5_EN? P3V3_S5_EN is a typo of P3V3S5_EN which is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
This board has no visible damage. It seemed like a straightforward issue, as I found <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> to be shorted to GND. I traced it to <CAPACITOR>C8270</CAPACITOR>, which had shorted for unknown reasons. After removing it, the short was gone, but still no power on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. I replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> with a good looking one from a donor board. Machine turned on and I got an image on screen, but it shut down mid-boot and wont turn back on.

Measured: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 'jumping around'. It has a sawtooth pattern on my scope.
I first suspected <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> - may have been a bad chip or poor soldering. I took it off and replaced it with another one. No change.

Other components on the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> rail look fine. No liquid or other damage found anywhere.

Measurements:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is mostly 0V but has little spikes up to ~1.5V

<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> are all showing a block pattern on scope.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 8.7V

Where to from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
Try first to start in SMC bypass.

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is mostly 0V but has little spikes up to ~1.5V"
Then <SIGNAL>XV_S4</SIGNAL> voltages should pulse too.
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>XV_S3</SIGNAL> voltages pulse.
Do the same for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and all <SIGNAL>XV_S0</SIGNAL>.
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

BTW, check the board alone, w/o tp/kb connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
Yeah, I'm working with just the board.
Found out <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is shorted to GND.. I hooked up lab supply to it; Nothing getting hot with 4A at 1V.
Short to GND inside the board, I guess? :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message: Inject 5 volts into <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> and see what heats up 1v is too low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
Nothing on the board heats up, at least not quickly; my (fairly thick) wire soldered to the board does smoke and its insulation melts at 5V / 10A (my power supply's max current)
If I leave it on 1V for a longer period a large area around my jumper's location heats up, but nothing specific. (I've attached my wire at pad 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7657</CAPACITOR>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
An IR cam can help you in this case.
FLIR is the best option, but Seek Cam (phone adapter) could be good enough too.
If your desk power supply is 10A limit, then start with 1V and increase voltage until get 9-9.5A.
If power supply indicates 10A can get stuck and doesn't really inject.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
I have a FLIR pro on a ipad on my bench. I consider it one of my most important tools. I grab that thing multiple times a day. It will pay for it's self the first week you own it. The software interface glitches and it is a pain in the ass at times but I would not part with it.  

You defiantly want a "Pro" the resolution is so important.  FLIR also overlays visual data with IR data so you can pinpoint the exact part.  I can literally identify a specific cap on a phone board and pluck it off. I use it on iPads all the time and MacBooks when trying to find which Tantalum is dead.  I have made thousands off the thing!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message: I'll think about it, but not in such a hurry that I'll get one just for this repair. I'll lift stuff off the board for this rail and see where that gets me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
Frustrating board.. I found out why <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> was short to GND; <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> was faulty. internal short, probably. I replaced it, Short gone, but no voltage on the rail still. Fed the rail 5V through my lab supply, no issues there.

Replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> again to rule that out. Got 8.7V on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>. <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> burnt up again.

Found that <RESISTOR>R7672</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7673</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7693</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7692</RESISTOR> are way off from what the schematic says they should be:

<RESISTOR>R7672</RESISTOR> was 25K, schematic says 10K
<RESISTOR>R7673</RESISTOR> was 2K, schem says 1K

<RESISTOR>R7692</RESISTOR> was 17K, schem says 15K
<RESISTOR>R7693</RESISTOR> was 2.7K, schem says 1K

This seems a little dubious to me, for all those resistors to be off like that, but I dont have a donor boards for this model to verify. Anyone know?

Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7672</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7673</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7692</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7693</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7673</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7693</CAPACITOR> all at once.
Hooked up adapter, heard a high pitched whine, notice amperage going up - whine stops, current draw back to 0.01 (voltage 20). Hooking it up again results in no whine and 0.01 Amps. So, it seems that <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> is dying every time I replace it, but I'm out of ideas on what might be causing it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
Dove into this board again today. Recap;

1. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> was shorted to GND through <CAPACITOR>C8270</CAPACITOR>. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C8270</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>. Machine worked, then stopped.

2. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> was mostly 0V but had spikes. <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> all had block shaped waves on scope. I found out that <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> was causing a short to GND and replaced it. Short gone, block shapes gone on other rails and everything seemingly ok, but 0V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>.

3. Replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> again and got 8.7V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. I failed to notice a bridge between <CAPACITOR>C7650</CAPACITOR> (PPBUS) and <CAPACITOR>C7653</CAPACITOR> (<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_REG3</SIGNAL>). Ouch. This is what caused <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> to go to 8.7V and probably killed <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> again. It probably did more than that.

Today, I removed the bridge between <CAPACITOR>C7650</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7653</CAPACITOR>, replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>.
Machine wont boot in SMC bypass. Power draw 0.02A at 20V.

Having had <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> at 8.7V, anything on that rail might be fried, including the SMC. Nothing special happens when I inject 5V into the rail now (0.08A).
Is there anything left to do to see if this is salvageable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> woes
threads.message:
It is watse of time.
Will end with dead CPU, as all <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> machines...
